docs.lead_paragraph: It was a pleasant Saturday morning and Marie Bettoni, a 17-year-old graduate of a Brooklyn high school, had dutifully accompanied her mother and father to a church wedding. Her parents went on to the reception; she returned home.

headline.main: Suicide Now No.2 Cause Of Deaths Among Young

docs.snippet: It was a pleasant Saturday morning and Marie Bettoni, a 17-year-old graduate of a Brooklyn high school, had dutifully accompanied her mother and father to a church wedding. Her parents went on to the reception; she returned home.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a pleasant Saturday morning and Marie Bettoni, a 17-year-old graduate of a Brooklyn high school, had dutifully accompanied her mother and father to a church wedding. Her parents went on to the reception; she returned home.

headline.main: Suicide Now No. 2 Cause Of Deaths Among Young; Suicide: Second Leading Cause of Death Among People 15 to 24

docs.abstract: Survey on suicides estimates that between 70,000-80,000 young people, between ages of 15-24, will attempt suicide within next yr; repts that between 3,500-4,000 of them are likely to succeed; notes that in last 25 yrs, suicide has become considered 2d leading cause of death among young; records in Los Angeles County, one of few places in US where careful statistics on suicides are kept, show that youth suicidal rate based on population has far more than doubled in last 10 yrs; rates for males and females according to age noted; Dr M L Peck, Los Angeles clinical psychologist and dir of youth studies at Suicide Prevention Center and Inst for Studies of Self-Destructive Behavior, contends that any large city not showing marked increase in young suicides is probably not keeping accurate records; discusses various reasons for increasing number of young suicides and suicide attempts; says that all suicide studies note that more girls attempt suicide but more boys succeed; C J Frederick, formerly with Natl Inst of Mental Health, speculates on reasons why young people commit suicide
docs.snippet: It was a pleasant Saturday morning and Marie Bettoni, a 17-year-old graduate of a Brooklyn high school, had dutifully accompanied her mother and father to a church wedding. Her parents went on to the reception; she returned home.
